title: How to Make Vegan Eggnog

steps.headline: Obtain your materials.
steps.description: Making vegan eggnog with cashews requires one cup of raw, unsalted cashews, pitted medjool dates, nutmeg, salt, and a can of coconut milk. You’ll also need two cups of water and can, if you choose, add one tablespoon of maple syrup. Be sure to get unsalted cashews or your eggnog will have a salty taste. This recipe will make about two cups of nog.

steps.headline: Soak the cashews for at least four hours.
steps.description: Put your cashews in a bowl or cup and cover them with water. Many people find it convenient to soak the cashews in the fridge overnight. This helps soften them so they are ready for processing later. Some recipes recommend rinsing the cashews after soaking and discarding the water, but it is not necessary to rinse them.

steps.headline: Soak the dates.
steps.description: In order to better draw out their sweetness, you could soak the dates in warm water for about an hour. You might notice the water start to darken or see the dates plump up. This is normal and indicates the dates are absorbing water and releasing their sugar.

steps.headline: Blend your cashews with two cups of water.
steps.description: After you’re done soaking your cashews, drain the water from them and place them in a blender or food processor with two cups of fresh water. Blend until the mixture is uniformly smooth. Do not use the same water you used to soak the cashews.

steps.headline: Add the other ingredients.
steps.description: Once the cashews and water are blended to a smooth consistency, you’ll need to add 1/4 teaspoon of salt, six to eight pitted dates, one teaspoon of nutmeg, one 14-ounce can of coconut milk, and (if you wish) one tablespoon of maple syrup. Blend everything for several minutes until the mixture is smooth.

steps.headline: Enjoy your eggnog.
steps.description: Place your eggnog in the fridge for half an hour to chill. Pour yourself or your friends a glass when it is ready. If you wish, add ice to the cup. Top with cinnamon or nutmeg. Store eggnog you don’t drink in the fridge, covered, and drink within three days.

steps.headline: Collect your ingredients.
steps.description: To make vegan eggnog with almonds, you need water, one cup of raw almonds, one cup of shredded, unsweetened coconut, pitted medjool dates, one teaspoon of nutmeg, and half of a vanilla bean. The vanilla bean section should be about five inches in length. The amount of water you add depends on how much nog you want to make. Adding two cups of water will produce 1.5 cups of nog. Adding three cups of water will produce about 2.25 cups of nog.

steps.headline: Soak the almonds.
steps.description: Add the almonds in a large bowl. Pour water over the almonds so that it covers them. Set the bowl aside overnight. Placing the almonds in water allows them to soften and makes them easier to blend. It also increases the digestibility of the nut and increases your ability to absorb the nutrients within.

steps.headline: Bake the raw coconut.
steps.description: Preheat your oven to 325 degrees Fahrenheit (163 degrees Celsius). Place the coconut in an even layer on a baking sheet. Check on it every three minutes until it is golden brown. The process will usually take about ten minutes. Remove when done and let cool.

steps.headline: Rinse the almonds.
steps.description: Dispose of the water the almonds soaked in. Pour the nuts into a colander and place it under running tap water. Run your hands through the almonds, rinsing them for about twenty seconds. Turn the tap off and give the colander a shake to help it drain.

steps.headline: Blend your ingredients.
steps.description: Add the nuts, vanilla bean, two or three cups of water, soaked dates, toasted coconut, and nutmeg to a blender. Pulse the ingredients for ten seconds, pause briefly, then pulse for another ten seconds. Set the blender on high. Blend everything for about one or two minutes, until smooth. If you wish, you can hold off on adding the nutmeg until after straining the mixture. You could also choose to soak the dates in warm water for one hour before adding the to the blender. This will draw out their sweetness.

steps.headline: Strain the mixture.
steps.description: Once you’ve blended everything up, you’ll need to strain out the almond pulp and bean bits. Place a nut milk bag over a mixing bowl or large pot and pour the blended mix slowly into the bag. The bag will filter the pulp and leave you with smooth, tasty nog in the bowl. If you did not add the nutmeg when blending your ingredients, you can whisk it in now. If you do not have a nut milk bag, you could use a cheesecloth or a mesh strainer. These alternatives will allow more pulp into the final product, though.

steps.headline: Make a boozy eggnog.
steps.description: If you are of legal drinking age, you could give your eggnog a kick. Splash a shot of bourbon, rum, or whiskey in the eggnog when you blend it. Add as much or as little as you want.

steps.headline: Thicken your eggnog.
steps.description: If you like a richer, fattier eggnog, you could leave the nut pulp in the eggnog after blending the nuts and water. If you choose to do this, simply add the rest of your ingredient to the mixture without straining it. Alternately, you could strain the pulp out, then add a portion of it back to the mixture after straining it out. For instance, if you want your nog just a bit thicker, you could scoop a table spoon or two of the strained nuts when blending the mix for the final time.

steps.headline: Make a thinner eggnog.
steps.description: If the eggnog is too thick for your tastes, add a few extra tablespoons of water before blending it for the final time. This will reduce the thickness of the nog. You could also add ice to your cup before pouring yourself a glass. As the ice melts, it will add water to the beverage, making it thinner.

steps.headline: Take the lazy way.
steps.description: Cashew and almond milk are readily available in grocery stores. If you’re impatient or just too busy to make your own milk alternative, you could buy one at your local grocery store. You could also use soy milk, though the higher fat content in cashew milk and almond milk make them more appropriate for eggnog. You could also save time by using vanilla extract instead of vanilla bean. One teaspoon per two to three cups of water should be enough.

steps.headline: Use different nuts.
steps.description: Instead of almonds or cashews, try raw, unsalted pecans or walnuts. These adjustments can change the flavor profile of your tasty nog. Pecans are sweeter than walnuts, and have a more mild taste. Walnuts have a rich flavor and blend well.

steps.headline: Add a sweet note to your nog.
steps.description: Toss half a frozen banana into the mix before blending everything to give the nog a fruity flavor. You could also play with the spice content of the nog by adding or removing nutmeg, cinnamon, or pumpkin spice. Alternately (or additionally), you could add a tablespoon or two of maple syrup to the blend.

text: Creating Eggnog With Cashews Obtain your materials. Making vegan eggnog with cashews requires one cup of raw, unsalted cashews, pitted medjool dates, nutmeg, salt, and a can of coconut milk. You’ll also need two cups of water and can, if you choose, add one tablespoon of maple syrup. Be sure to get unsalted cashews or your eggnog will have a salty taste. This recipe will make about two cups of nog. Soak the cashews for at least four hours. Put your cashews in a bowl or cup and cover them with water. Many people find it convenient to soak the cashews in the fridge overnight. This helps soften them so they are ready for processing later. Some recipes recommend rinsing the cashews after soaking and discarding the water, but it is not necessary to rinse them. Soak the dates. In order to better draw out their sweetness, you could soak the dates in warm water for about an hour. You might notice the water start to darken or see the dates plump up. This is normal and indicates the dates are absorbing water and releasing their sugar. Blend your cashews with two cups of water. After you’re done soaking your cashews, drain the water from them and place them in a blender or food processor with two cups of fresh water. Blend until the mixture is uniformly smooth. Do not use the same water you used to soak the cashews. Add the other ingredients. Once the cashews and water are blended to a smooth consistency, you’ll need to add 1/4 teaspoon of salt, six to eight pitted dates, one teaspoon of nutmeg, one 14-ounce can of coconut milk, and (if you wish) one tablespoon of maple syrup. Blend everything for several minutes until the mixture is smooth. Enjoy your eggnog. Place your eggnog in the fridge for half an hour to chill. Pour yourself or your friends a glass when it is ready. If you wish, add ice to the cup. Top with cinnamon or nutmeg. Store eggnog you don’t drink in the fridge, covered, and drink within three days. Making Eggnog With Almonds Collect your ingredients. To make vegan eggnog with almonds, you need water, one cup of raw almonds, one cup of shredded, unsweetened coconut, pitted medjool dates, one teaspoon of nutmeg, and half of a vanilla bean. The vanilla bean section should be about five inches in length. The amount of water you add depends on how much nog you want to make. Adding two cups of water will produce 1.5 cups of nog. Adding three cups of water will produce about 2.25 cups of nog. Soak the almonds. Add the almonds in a large bowl. Pour water over the almonds so that it covers them. Set the bowl aside overnight. Placing the almonds in water allows them to soften and makes them easier to blend. It also increases the digestibility of the nut and increases your ability to absorb the nutrients within. Bake the raw coconut. Preheat your oven to 325 degrees Fahrenheit (163 degrees Celsius). Place the coconut in an even layer on a baking sheet. Check on it every three minutes until it is golden brown. The process will usually take about ten minutes. Remove when done and let cool. Rinse the almonds. Dispose of the water the almonds soaked in. Pour the nuts into a colander and place it under running tap water. Run your hands through the almonds, rinsing them for about twenty seconds. Turn the tap off and give the colander a shake to help it drain. Blend your ingredients. Add the nuts, vanilla bean, two or three cups of water, soaked dates, toasted coconut, and nutmeg to a blender. Pulse the ingredients for ten seconds, pause briefly, then pulse for another ten seconds. Set the blender on high. Blend everything for about one or two minutes, until smooth. If you wish, you can hold off on adding the nutmeg until after straining the mixture. You could also choose to soak the dates in warm water for one hour before adding the to the blender. This will draw out their sweetness. Strain the mixture. Once you’ve blended everything up, you’ll need to strain out the almond pulp and bean bits. Place a nut milk bag over a mixing bowl or large pot and pour the blended mix slowly into the bag. The bag will filter the pulp and leave you with smooth, tasty nog in the bowl. If you did not add the nutmeg when blending your ingredients, you can whisk it in now. If you do not have a nut milk bag, you could use a cheesecloth or a mesh strainer. These alternatives will allow more pulp into the final product, though. Experimenting With Your Eggnog Make a boozy eggnog. If you are of legal drinking age, you could give your eggnog a kick. Splash a shot of bourbon, rum, or whiskey in the eggnog when you blend it. Add as much or as little as you want. Thicken your eggnog. If you like a richer, fattier eggnog, you could leave the nut pulp in the eggnog after blending the nuts and water. If you choose to do this, simply add the rest of your ingredient to the mixture without straining it. Alternately, you could strain the pulp out, then add a portion of it back to the mixture after straining it out. For instance, if you want your nog just a bit thicker, you could scoop a table spoon or two of the strained nuts when blending the mix for the final time. Make a thinner eggnog. If the eggnog is too thick for your tastes, add a few extra tablespoons of water before blending it for the final time. This will reduce the thickness of the nog. You could also add ice to your cup before pouring yourself a glass. As the ice melts, it will add water to the beverage, making it thinner. Take the lazy way. Cashew and almond milk are readily available in grocery stores. If you’re impatient or just too busy to make your own milk alternative, you could buy one at your local grocery store. You could also use soy milk, though the higher fat content in cashew milk and almond milk make them more appropriate for eggnog. You could also save time by using vanilla extract instead of vanilla bean. One teaspoon per two to three cups of water should be enough. Use different nuts. Instead of almonds or cashews, try raw, unsalted pecans or walnuts. These adjustments can change the flavor profile of your tasty nog. Pecans are sweeter than walnuts, and have a more mild taste. Walnuts have a rich flavor and blend well. Add a sweet note to your nog. Toss half a frozen banana into the mix before blending everything to give the nog a fruity flavor. You could also play with the spice content of the nog by adding or removing nutmeg, cinnamon, or pumpkin spice. Alternately (or additionally), you could add a tablespoon or two of maple syrup to the blend.
